cluster_relations.rel_desc: Participation in sports leads to the development of life skills.
cluster_relations.object_class_label: Life Skills and Lessons from Sports

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Participation in sports helps individuals develop teamwork.
cluster_relations.object_class_label: Life Skills and Lessons from Sports
remarks: More granular relation derived from the enumerated list.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Participation in sports helps individuals develop perseverance.
cluster_relations.object_class_label: Life Skills and Lessons from Sports

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Participation in sports helps individuals develop resilience.
cluster_relations.object_class_label: Life Skills and Lessons from Sports

qualifiers.TemporalQualifier: with repeated exposure to challenges in sports

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Sports provide lessons such as cooperation and dealing with success and failure.
cluster_relations.object_class_label: Life Skills and Lessons from Sports

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: LessonContent: cooperation, overcoming obstacles, handling success and failure

remarks: Relation created to capture source of lessons; text is slightly indirect.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject activity or domain (e.g., participation in sports, sports) causally promotes the development or acquisition of the object skills, traits, or lessons in participants.
args.justification: All five relations describe a causal effect where engaging in sports (or participation in sports) leads to the development or acquisition of life skills, specific personal traits (teamwork, perseverance, resilience), or broader lessons. A unified predicate 'promotes_development_of' captures this causal educational/skill-development semantics across these instances better than the raw verb 'develops' or 'provides'.

Each relation connects sports participation (or sports as a domain) to the development of life skills, traits, or lessons, forming a coherent family of causal relations about personal skill/competence development driven by an activity.

The descriptions and rel_hint_type explicitly indicate a causal effect (sports participation leads to / helps develop / provides lessons), so these relations belong in a causal group rather than a purely associative one.
